questions.text:
Two hours after undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, a 44-year-old man has nausea and pain at the site of surgery. He has vomited twice in the past hour. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include insulin, atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, acetaminophen, and prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. He drinks two to three beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. He is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 130 kg (286 lb); BMI is 42 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Examination shows five laparoscopic incisions with no erythema or discharge. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. There is mild diffuse tenderness to palpation. Bowel sounds are reduced. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
45%


Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 K+

3.5 mEq/L


 Cl-

98 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
31 mg/dL


 Glucose
88 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.28


Pco2

32 mm Hg


Po2
54 mm Hg


HCO3-
14.4 mEq/L


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acid-base status?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient underwent Roux-en-Y bypass, which puts him at risk of developing blind loop syndrome. However, blind loop syndrome is a long-term complication of gastric surgery and would not be expected to develop within 2 hours of surgery. Furthermore, it typically does not result in a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Instead, patients may develop non-anion gap metabolic acidosis from chronic diarrhea and subsequent loss of bicarbonate.

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) can develop in patients with diabetes mellitus (DM) during times of increased insulin demand (e.g., surgery, infection) and typically leads to high anion gap metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. However, this patient does not have other typical features of DKA, such as hyperglycemia, ketonuria, polyuria, polydipsia, signs of volume depletion, neurological abnormalities, and a fruity breath odor. In addition, DKA is much more common in type 1 DM than in type 2 DM.

C) INCORRECT:

Alcohol withdrawal can result in metabolic acidosis with an elevated anion gap in malnourished patients with alcohol use disorder, especially those with a history of binge drinking. During alcohol ingestion, alcoholic carbohydrates are metabolized into energy, inhibiting fatty acid metabolism. However, as a response to alcohol withdrawal, there is a surge in catecholamines and cortisol which augments the metabolism of a fasting state. Consequently, lipolysis and ketone acid production are increased, resulting in metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap (alcoholic ketoacidosis). Although this man's alcohol consumption is borderline high, he does not have any other signs of alcohol withdrawal (e.g., tremors, altered mental state, or hallucinations), nor is he malnourished, making alcohol withdrawal an unlikely etiology of his acid-base disturbance.

D) INCORRECT:

Repeated vomiting can result in a significant loss of HCl, NaCl, and KCl, leading to a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis that can be further aggravated by hypovolemia (contraction alkalosis). This patient has metabolic acidosis, which is unlikely to be caused by vomiting.

E) INCORRECT:

Dumping syndrome is a complication of gastric surgery, including Roux-en-Y bypass surgery. Symptoms of early dumping syndrome include nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. However, metabolic acidosis is not a typical feature of dumping syndrome. Furthermore, it is unlikely that this patient has developed dumping syndrome only 2 hours after surgery because he is unlikely to have eaten anything yet.

F) CORRECT:

In patients with hypoxia, the lack of oxygen supply to the affected tissue results in anaerobic metabolism and the production of lactic acid, an unmeasured organic anion that lowers the pH. This subsequently causes metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Obese patients who undergo bariatric surgery frequently develop temporary postoperative hypoxemia, as seen in this patient with pO2 of 54 mm Hg. While the pathophysiology behind this is not completely understood, atelectasis-associated ventilation-perfusion mismatch is likely to play a role.
Image Description:

This algorithm does not account for mixed acid-base disorders.

Cl-: chloride
HCO3-: bicarbonate
Na+: sodium
PCO2: partial pressure of carbon dioxide
questions.hint: This patient's arterial blood gas analysis indicates metabolic acidosis (pH < 7.35, bicarbonate < 22) with respiratory compensation (pCO2  < 35 mm Hg). His high anion gap (136 mEq/l - (98 mEq/L + 14.4 mEq/L) = 23.6 mEq/L) suggests the accumulation of an unmeasured organic anion.

questions.text: A previously healthy 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department immediately after an episode of loss of consciousness. He was standing in line at a bus stop when he suddenly became tense, fell down, and lost consciousness; this was followed by 4 minutes of violent jerky movements of his arms and legs. He was confused after the episode. He has no recollection of the event or its immediate aftermath. On arrival, he is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His temperature is 37.7째C (99.4째F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows blood in the mouth. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypercalcemia most often arises secondary to hyperparathyroidism or malignancy. Although severe hypocalcemia can cause seizures, hypercalcemia generally does not, making it an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms. During high-exertion activities (e.g., generalized muscle contractions) in which oxygen delivery to the tissue is inadequate, muscles use anaerobic respiration, which can cause lactic acidosis. Lactic acidosis increases the serum concentrations of ionized calcium due to the competition of hydrogen ions with calcium for the same binding site on albumin. Although serum ionized calcium concentration increases in this scenario, total calcium concentration remains unchanged.

B) INCORRECT:

Creatine kinase (CK) is a breakdown product of muscle and is usually elevated, not reduced, after an exertional event such as a seizure. Severe and/or prolonged seizures can even result in rhabdomyolysis with significantly elevated levels of serum CK.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypernatremia has numerous etiologies, including dehydration, hypertonic saline infusion, and diabetes insipidus, but it is most often seen in patients of advanced age. Seizures may occur in the setting of severe hypernatremia (> 158 mEq/L) but would generally be preceded by fatigue, weakness, lethargy, or muscle twitching. In this young and previously healthy 24-year-old patient with no prior symptoms, hypernatremia would be unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypoprolactinemia most often arises secondary to hypopituitarism or ingestion of dopamine receptor agonists. In the postictal period, however, serum prolactin levels are usually elevated. The mechanism underlying prolactin secretion during seizures is not completely understood, though it may result from excessive electrical stimulation and consequent activation of the hypothalamic pituitary axis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient had a tonic-clonic seizure and is now likely experiencing postictal lactic acidosis, an anion gap metabolic acidosis that manifests with a reduced serum bicarbonate concentration. During tonic-clonic seizures, excess muscle exertion results in inadequate oxygen delivery to the tissue, followed by anaerobic respiration and an increase in serum lactate. Postictal acidosis is transient and typically resolves within two hours. Therapy with IV bicarbonate is not needed; rather, electrolytes and arterial blood gases should be monitored until they normalize. An EEG can help guide decisions on the need for long-term anticonvulsant therapy.

Further laboratory abnormalities in patients who have experienced tonic-clonic seizures include hyperprolactinemia, increased creatine kinase, elevated cortisol, elevated white blood cell count, neuron-specific enolase, and lactate dehydrogenase. However, these findings are not specific and therefore not commonly used to diagnose tonic-clonic seizures.

F) INCORRECT:

Hypermagnesemia is an uncommon laboratory finding that usually occurs as a result of kidney failure and often exists concurrently with other electrolyte disturbances. Symptoms are generally nonspecific, but can include muscle weakness, nausea, and vomiting. Though hypomagnesemia can cause seizures, hypermagnesemia generally does not, making it an unlikely finding in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient recently had a tonic-clonic seizure with 4 minutes of highly exertional upper and lower extremity movement. Which of the following findings can be seen following a period of intense muscle exertion in the setting of inadequate oxygen supply?

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 10 hours after ingesting approximately 40 tablets of aspirin. He is dizzy and nauseated but has not vomited. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 105/66 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness. Mental status examination shows confusion. He is oriented to person but not to time or place. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L and a chloride concentration of 103 mEq/L. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



pH
PaCO2 (mm Hg)
HCO3- (mEq/L)



A
7.43
30
19


B
7.46
48
33


C
7.41
42
26


D
7.55
31
26


E
7.36
50
27


F
7.22
50
20


G
7.44
47
31
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The time that has elapsed since aspirin ingestion indicates that the patient would have both HAGMA and respiratory alkalosis. A low HCO3- concentration is consistent with metabolic acidosis and an anion gap that is expectedly high (18 mEq/L) is obtained when using the measured Na+ and Cl- concentrations and an HCO3- concentration of 19 mEq/L. For a patient with metabolic acidosis, the Winter formula, i.e., expected PaCO2 = (1.5 x HCO3-) + 8 (+/- 2), is used to estimate the expected change in PaCO2 by physiological compensation alone. In order to be consistent with an additional respiratory alkalosis, the measured PaCO2 must be less than the expected PaCO2. For an HCO3- concentration of 19 mEq/L, a measured PaCO2 of 30 mm Hg is lower than the expected PaCO2 (34.538.5 mm Hg) and is therefore consistent with the expected findings. In patients with mixed acidosis and alkalosis, the pH can be normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Alkalemia with a high PaCO2 (48 mm Hg) indicates a metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic alkalosis can occur in patients with aspirin toxicity as a result of severe vomiting. However, this patient has not vomited following aspirin ingestion.

C) INCORRECT:

This set of arterial blood gas findings is normal. This patient, who has manifestations of the late phase of aspirin toxicity, is unlikely to have normal arterial blood gas findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Alkalemia with low PaCO2 (31 mm Hg), normal bicarbonate (26 mEq/L), and a normal anion gap (11 mEq/L) indicates a noncompensated respiratory alkalosis. Respiratory alkalosis develops in the early phase of salicylate toxicity. However, several hours after salicylate ingestion, patients also develop a high anion gap metabolic acidosis that results in a mixed acid-base disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

A normal pH (7.36) with high PaCO2 (50 mm Hg), normal bicarbonate (27 mEq/L), and a normal anion gap (10 mEq/L) indicates a noncompensated respiratory acidosis. This patient, who is hyperventilating, is unlikely to have a respiratory acidosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Acidemia with high PaCO2 (50 mm Hg), low bicarbonate (20 mEq/L), and a high anion gap (17 mEq/L) indicates a respiratory acidosis with an additional high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA). Patients with salicylate poisoning usually develop a HAGMA due to the accumulation of lactic acid, organic ketoacids, and salicylate. Occasionally, respiratory acidosis can occur with severe salicylate toxicity as a result of CNS depression and hypoventilation. However, this patient, who is hyperventilating, is unlikely to have a respiratory acidosis.

G) INCORRECT:

A normal pH of 7.44 with high PaCO2 (47 mm Hg), high bicarbonate (31 mEq/L), and a normal anion gap (6 mEq/L) indicates a combination of metabolic alkalosis and respiratory acidosis. Another mixed acid-base disorder should be suspected in patients with salicylate overdose.
questions.hint: In the early phase of aspirin toxicity, patients develop respiratory alkalosis as a result of hyperventilation (due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center in the medulla by salicylate). In the late phase, which occurs several hours after ingestion, patients develop an additional high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) primarily because salicylate uncouples mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation and increases the conversion of acetyl-CoA and pyruvate to ketoacids and lactate respectively.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician for the evaluation of fatigue for the past 6 months. During this period, she has had a 5-kg (11-lbs) weight loss. She states that she has no friends. When she is not in school, she spends most of her time in bed. She has no history of serious illness. Her mother has major depressive disorder. She appears pale. She is at 25th percentile for height, 15th percentile for weight, and 20th percentile for BMI; her BMI is 19 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0째C (98.6째F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dry skin, brittle nails, and calluses on the knuckles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.3 g/dL


Serum



Na+

133 mEq/L


Cl-

90 mEq/L


K+

3.2 mEq/L


HCO3-

30 mEq/L


Ca2+

7.8 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While anemia can cause fatigue, this patient's hemoglobin is within normal limits. Additionally, anemia on its own would not explain the electrolyte abnormalities present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Milk-alkali syndrome causes metabolic alkalosis, but is associated with hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, from excessive ingestion of calcium.

C) INCORRECT:

While anorexia nervosa can cause metabolic alkalosis, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypochloremia, and may be associated with dry skin and calluses on knuckles from self-induced vomiting, the body mass index (BMI) in anorexia nervosa is by definition low (< 10th percentile for patients 20 years of age and < 18.5 kg/m2 for patients > 20 years of age), not normal.

D) INCORRECT:

While this patient has symptoms that are suggestive of major depressive disorder (MDD) such as fatigue, weight change, and sleep disturbance, she does not meet the diagnostic criteria for MDD. Hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, and calluses on the knuckles with a normal body mass index suggest a different diagnosis that may be associated with MDD.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can cause fatigue, brittle nails, hyponatremia, and hypokalemia, but is not generally associated with metabolic alkalosis. Additionally, patients with hypothyroidism would likely present with weight gain, not weight loss. Additional features of hypothyroidism may include cold intolerance, hair loss, constipation, myxedema, and/or amenorrhea.

F) CORRECT:

Repeated purging in bulimia nervosa can cause metabolic alkalosis, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypochloremia, as well as dry skin and calluses on the knuckles (Russell sign) from self-induced vomiting. By definition, the body mass index (BMI) in patients with bulimia nervosa is normal or elevated (> 10th percentile for children). Treatment with cognitive behavioral therapy (first line) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors may help prevent additional complications such as esophagitis, poor dentition, cardiac arrhythmias, and hypotension.

G) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism can manifest with fatigue, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, hypocalcemia, and hypochloremia, but is generally associated with mild hypernatremia or normonatremia (not hyponatremia). Additionally, hyperaldosteronism would manifest with hypertension (often severe). Moreover, this diagnosis would not explain the patient's dry skin, brittle nails, and calluses on the knuckles.
questions.hint: This patient presents with metabolic alkalosis, hyponatremia, hypochloremia, hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and skin manifestations (dry skin, calluses on the knuckles). Together with a normal BMI, these features are consistent with a specific diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness and abdominal pain for the past day. Since this morning, he has also had nausea and two episodes of vomiting. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include insulin and atorvastatin, although he admits that he has not taken his medication for the past few days. He appears drowsy. His temperature is 37.8째C (100.4째F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. He has a fruity odor to his breath. Abdominal examination shows epigastric tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.3 g/dL


Leukocyte count
11,300/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

135 mEq/L


 K+

5.1 mEq/L

15 mg/dL

Which of the following sets of arterial blood gas findings would most likely be found in this patient?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acidemia with decreased bicarbonate indicates metabolic acidosis, which would be expected in this patient's condition. However, a measured pCO2 greater than the expected value of pCO2 based on Winter formula is consistent with an added respiratory acidosis. Increased pCO2 would not be expected in this hyperventilating patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Alkalemia with low pCO2 indicates respiratory alkalosis, which can occur secondary to hyperventilation, e.g., during a panic attack. Alkalemia would not be expected in this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Acidemia with decreased bicarbonate is consistent with metabolic acidosis. However, for this set of values, the patient's anion gap is 135 - (114 + 15) = 6 mEq/L, which is normal. Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis would be seen in patients with renal tubular acidosis or gastrointestinal loss of HCO3- (e.g., secondary to diarrhea). The accumulation of ketones in this patient's condition would result in an increased anion gap.

D) INCORRECT:

Normal arterial blood gas results and a normal anion gap can be seen in a hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS), which can cause an altered mental status, features of dehydration, and possibly vomiting. However, the onset of symptoms is more insidious in HHS, and abdominal pain and a fruity breath odor are not features of this condition. Moreover, HHS usually occurs in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and manifests with a serum glucose concentration 600 mg/dL. A different hyperglycemic crisis is more likely in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

This set of arterial blood gas findings is expected in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the most likely cause of abdominal pain, vomiting, dehydration (dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor), and altered mental status in a patient with type 1 diabetes mellitus and nonadherence to insulin therapy. Insulin deficiency triggers lipolysis, which generates free fatty acids that become ketones, resulting in a high anion gap (135 mEq/L - [98 mEq/L + 9 mEq/L] = 28 mEq/L). The primary acid-base disturbance in DKA is metabolic acidosis and patients, therefore, develop acidemia with decreased bicarbonate. Winter formula, i.e., expected pCO2 (mm Hg) = (1.5 HCO3) + 8 짹 2, is used to identify the presence of a secondary acid-base disorder. In this patient expected pCO2 is 21.5 짹 2, which means there is respiratory compensation (from hyperventilation) and no added respiratory acid-base disorder.

In patients with a hyperglycemic crisis, the measured sodium concentration should be used to calculate the anion gap. The corrected serum sodium concentration is only used to calculate water deficits and guide fluid management.

F) INCORRECT:

Alkalemia with high bicarbonate is consistent with a primary metabolic alkalosis. While metabolic alkalosis can occur as a result of repeated vomiting, this patient's condition is associated with a different primary acid-base disorder.
questions.hint: A urine dipstick test in this patient would be positive for ketones. The anion gap = [Na+] - ([Cl-] + [HCO3-]).

questions.text:
Two days after undergoing a left hemicolectomy for diverticulitis, a 61-year-old man reports increasing sharp lower chest pain and shortness of breath over the past 24 hours. The pain worsens when he takes a deep breath. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. His current medications include lisinopril, aspirin, metoprolol, and hydromorphone for pain control. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He does not drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.5째C (99.5째F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. On pulmonary examination, decreased breath sounds are heard over the right lower lung field. Tactile fremitus is decreased. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows elevation of the right diaphragm and opacification of the right lower lung zone. Arterial blood gas analysis is most likely to show which of the following findings in this patient?



pH
pO2

pCO2

HCO3-




A
7.10
80 mmHg
60 mm Hg
18 mEq/L


B
7.29
98 mm Hg
61 mm Hg
28 mEq/L


C
7.34
100 mm Hg
25 mm Hg
13 mEq/L


D
7.51
200 mm Hg
29 mm Hg
22 mEq/L


E
7.49
70 mm Hg
28 mm Hg
21 mEq/L
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum pH with hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and low HCO3- suggests respiratory acidosis and metabolic acidosis, which can be seen in patients with sepsis and advanced acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The metabolic acidosis typically results from underlying sepsis, and with disease progression, patients with ARDS may develop hypercapnic respiratory failure due to respiratory exhaustion. A different acid-base disorder would be expected with atelectasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum pH and hypercapnia suggest respiratory acidosis, which can result from acute hypoventilation due to general anesthesia (e.g., respiratory muscle paralysis, sedative overdose), upper airway obstruction (e.g., laryngeal edema, blocked endotracheal tube), or an acute exacerbation of COPD or asthma, in which diffuse small airway obstruction occurs. A different acid-base disorder would be expected with the regional alveolar collapse characteristic of atelectasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum pH and low HCO3- suggest metabolic acidosis, which can occur during or after surgery and manifest with an elevated anion gap (e.g., lactic acidosis due to tissue hypoperfusion) or a normal anion gap (e.g., excessive saline infusion). A different acid-base disorder would be expected with atelectasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased pH with hypocapnia indicates respiratory alkalosis. Hyperoxemia with respiratory alkalosis suggests mechanical ventilation with an inappropriately high FiO2 and tidal volume as the most likely etiology. In a patient with atelectasis, hypoxemia would be expected.

E) CORRECT:

Postoperative atelectasis is one of the most common pulmonary complications in the first 72 hours after surgery. After chest or abdominal surgery, inadequately controlled postoperative pain discourages deep breathing (which is important for alveolar recruitment at the lung bases) and impairs coughing (which can lead to mucus plugging in an airway and absorption atelectasis). Patients subsequently develop regional alveolar collapse and hypoxemia from a ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch as well as a right-to-left pulmonary shunt in the area of atelectasis.

To compensate for the resulting hypoxemia, the patient hyperventilates to increase ventilation of the noncollapsed alveoli and often develops respiratory alkalosis (high pH, low pCO2). Hypoxemia due to a right-to-left pulmonary shunt cannot be improved by 100% O2 delivery; instead, alveolar recruitment needs to be facilitated using adequate analgesia and lung expansion maneuvers.
questions.hint: This patient's recent history of abdominal surgery, examination findings (diminished breath sounds and decreased tactile fremitus over the affected lung), and chest x-ray findings (opacification of the right lower lung zone with ipsilateral elevation of the diaphragm) indicate postoperative atelectasis.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with nausea and abdominal pain for 1 day. Her last bowel movement was 6 days ago. She has not passed flatus for 12 hours. She has a history of multiple surgeries for endometriosis. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a distended and diffusely tender abdomen with no rebound or guarding. Rectal examination shows an empty rectum. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a dilated cecum and right colon and preservation of the haustra. The patient is kept NPO (nothing by mouth). A nasogastric tube is inserted for continuous decompression and 900 ml (30 oz) of gastric fluid is drained. This intervention is most likely to lead to which of the following sets of serum findings?



pH
HCO3-

K+ 

Cl- 




A


unchanged
unchanged


B


unchanged
unchanged


C
Unchanged
unchanged

unchanged


D






E






F



unchanged
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap, e.g., due to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). In DKA, the accumulation of acidic ketone bodies leads to a marked decrease in pH. Serum bicarbonate (HCO3-) is low because it is consumed as a buffer. Despite actual total body potassium deficits, most patients with DKA present with normal potassium levels due to the shift of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space. Evacuation of gastric contents, however, removes acid from the body, which in turn leads to metabolic alkalosis.

B) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with metabolic alkalosis due to bicarbonate (HCO3-) excess. Etiologies include excessive administration of bicarbonate in a patient with renal impairment, and milk-alkali syndrome, a condition in which ingestion of large amounts of calcium in combination with antacid therapy interferes with renal bicarbonate excretion. Although evacuation of gastric contents typically leads to metabolic alkalosis, further serum electrolyte changes would be expected here.

C) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with hypokalemia, which can be caused by decreased potassium intake, increased potassium shift into cells (e.g., mediated by excessive insulin or beta-adrenergic activity), and increased gastrointestinal or urinary losses (e.g., vomiting, diuretics). Although extensive gastric fluid drainage will likely cause hypokalemia, further serum changes are expected.

D) CORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with metabolic alkalosis caused by a loss of gastric acid (e.g., due to nasogastric suction or vomiting). Since gastric acid mainly consists of hydrogen chloride (HCl), hypochloremia is expected. Although small quantities of potassium chloride (KCl) are also lost with the gastric fluid, volume depletion, which leads to secondary hyperaldosteronism and, consequently, stimulation of renal potassium excretion is the main cause of hypokalemia associated with continuous nasogastric decompression. Moreover, renal loss of hydrogen ions leads to an increased formation of bicarbonate (HCO3-). See Acid-base disturbances associated with GI disorders table.

E) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap, e.g., due to diarrhea. Diarrhea typically leads to the loss of large amounts of bicarbonate (HCO3-) and potassium. Primary loss of bicarbonate is compensated with an elevation of chloride, resulting in hyperchloremic acidosis. Evacuation of gastric contents, however, removes acid from the body, leading to subsequent metabolic alkalosis.

F) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with partially compensated respiratory alkalosis, as may be seen in hyperventilation. Hyperventilation leads to an increase in pH due to a CO2 washout (i.e., hypocapnia). As a compensatory response, renal bicarbonate (HCO3-) reabsorption is reduced, leading to decreased serum levels. Respiratory alkalosis is usually associated with hypokalemia due to a potassium shift from the extracellular space into cells. Although continuous nasogastric decompression also leads to an increase in pH, the loss of gastric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and, thus, an increase in bicarbonate.
questions.hint: Loss of gastric acid due to continuous nasogastric tube decompression leads to metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 2-day history of worsening shortness of breath. During the past week, she had a runny nose, mild sore throat, and a low-grade fever. She also has had a cough occasionally productive of sputum for the past 2 years. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. On examination, she occasionally has to catch her breath between sentences. Her temperature is 38.1째C (100.6째F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Expiratory wheezes with a prolonged expiratory phase are heard over both lung fields. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.33


PCO2
53 mm Hg


PO2

68 mm Hg


An x-ray of the chest shows hyperinflation of bilateral lung fields and flattening of the diaphragm. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A decrease in urinary HCO3- excretion is a compensatory measure in response to hypercapnia and chronic respiratory acidosis, which often occur in patients with COPD as a result of expiratory airway collapse and respiratory muscle fatigue. The proximal convoluted tubules reabsorb HCO3-, improving the buffer capacity of the serum against lower pH. The distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts in the kidneys also increase excretion of H+ (in the form of H2PO4 and NH4+), raising the blood pH to compensate for respiratory acidosis.
Image Description:

This algorithm does not account for mixed acid-base disorders.

Cl-: chloride
HCO3-: bicarbonate
Na+: sodium
PCO2: partial pressure of carbon dioxide

B) INCORRECT:

Increased urinary pH caused by the increased renal tubular excretion of HCO3- occurs as a compensatory mechanism in individuals with respiratory alkalosis. This patient's decreased arterial pH and increased PCO2, however, indicate respiratory acidosis, in which the compensatory mechanism is a decrease (not an increase) in urinary pH.

C) INCORRECT:

An increased serum anion gap occurs in high anion gap metabolic acidosis because of an accumulation of unmeasured ions (e.g., ammonium, butyrate, citrate, lactate). In respiratory acidosis, the serum anion gap typically remains unchanged.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypokalemia occurs in alkalemia through a shift of K+ ions from plasma into cellular compartments. Extracellular K+ exchanges with intracellular H+ as a compensatory mechanism to lower pH levels. In this patient with acidemia, hyperkalemia would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased urinary chloride concentration occurs in conditions that cause chloride-depletion metabolic alkalosis such as excessive vomiting or diuretic overuse. Respiratory acidosis is not associated with significant changes in urinary chloride concentration.
questions.hint: In this chronic smoker, worsening shortness of breath following an upper respiratory infection suggests an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Arterial blood gas analysis showing decreased pH and increased PCO2 is consistent with respiratory acidosis.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old primigravid woman at 8 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of nausea and vomiting. She has not been able to eat or drink much. Her symptoms are worse in the morning. She has tried multiple oral antiemetics with limited relief. She has not had fevers, chills, abdominal pain, urinary symptoms, or diarrhea. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37째C (98.6째F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes, and cool extremities with delayed capillary refill time. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.56


PCO2

40 mm Hg


PO2

94 mm Hg


HCO3-

30 mEq/L


Measurement of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Urine albumin to urine creatinine ratio

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The serum osmolal gap is useful in determining the etiology of high anion gap metabolic acidosis, especially when toxic alcohol ingestion (ethanol, methanol, or ethylene glycol) may have occurred. Measuring the serum osmolal gap does not help to determine the cause or guide the management of metabolic alkalosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The urine anion gap is measured as a proxy for urinary excretion of NH4+, which is a measure of renal acidification. It is useful in determining whether a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis is caused by inadequate renal acidification of urine. Measuring the urine anion gap does not help to determine the cause or guide the management of metabolic alkalosis.

C) INCORRECT:

The serum anion gap is measured when determining the cause of metabolic acidosis. Measuring the serum anion gap does not help to determine the cause or guide the management of metabolic alkalosis.

D) INCORRECT:

The urine albumin to creatinine ratio (UACR) is used to identify glomerular damage and screen for increased risk of kidney disease. Diseases that damage the glomerulus (e.g., diabetes and hypertension) cause excess excretion of albumin, which raises the UACR. Measuring the UACR does not help to determine the cause or guide the management of metabolic alkalosis.

E) CORRECT:

Measurement of urine chloride concentration is useful to determine the etiology of metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic alkalosis associated with a normal urine chloride concentration (< 25 mmol/L) is referred to as chloride-responsive metabolic alkalosis because it corrects with the administration of fluid with NaCl. It is often secondary to volume depletion through vomiting or loop diuretic use. In contrast, metabolic alkalosis associated with an elevated urine chloride concentration (> 40 mmol/L) is referred to as chloride-resistant metabolic alkalosis, as it does not correct with the administration of chloride-containing fluid. It is often secondary to underlying conditions, such as primary hyperaldosteronism or Cushing syndrome, and is associated with increased extracellular volume and hypertension.

This patient most likely has contraction alkalosis secondary to vomiting and therefore a normal urine chloride concentration would be expected.
Image Description:

ABG: arterial blood gas
BMP: basic metabolic panel
questions.hint: An arterial blood gas analysis with a pH of 7.56, pCO2 of 40 mm Hg, and HCO3- of 30 mEq/L is consistent with primary metabolic alkalosis. This patient's tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, cool extremities, and delayed capillary refill time suggest volume depletion, most likely secondary to persistent vomiting.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter because of a 2-day history of nonbloody diarrhea. The patient has had 810 bowel movements daily and has not vomited. She has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, atorvastatin, metoprolol, metformin, and dapagliflozin. She appears ill and sleepy. She is 157 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 109 kg (240 lb); BMI is 44 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.9째C (100.2 째F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. A fingerstick glucose test shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.24


PO2

85 mm Hg


PCO2
39 mm Hg


HCO3-
16 mEq/L


Which of the following is the most likely acid-base abnormality in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's low pH, low bicarbonate levels, and normal pCO2 levels suggest metabolic rather than respiratory acidosis as the primary acid-base disorder. In respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation, both pCO2 and HCO3- levels are expected to be increased, which is not seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's low pH, low bicarbonate levels, and normal pCO2 levels suggest metabolic acidosis as the primary acid-base disorder. However, in patients with concomitant respiratory alkalosis, pCO2 levels are expected to be lower rather than higher than expected.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis, pH is usually within the normal range, and both pCO2 and HCO3- levels are expected to be increased, which is not seen here. This patient's low pH, low bicarbonate levels, and normal pCO2 levels indicate metabolic rather than respiratory acidosis as the primary acid-base disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's low pH, low bicarbonate levels, and normal pCO2 levels suggest metabolic acidosis as the primary acid-base disorder. However, in patients with accompanying respiratory compensation, pH levels are expected to be within rather than below the normal range, and the pCO2 level would not be higher than expected.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's low pH and low bicarbonate levels suggest metabolic acidosis as the primary acid-base disorder. This patient's metabolic acidosis is most likely caused by diarrhea, which commonly leads to loss of bicarbonate, although metformin and dapagliflozin can also cause lactic acidosis and ketoacidosis, respectively. In patients with metabolic acidosis, the expected pCO2 concentration is calculated according to the Winter formula to check if the patient has developed the expected respiratory compensation. Patients with a pCO2 higher than expected, as seen here, have concomitant respiratory acidosis. The failed respiratory compensation and consequent mixed acid-base disorder in this patient with morbid obesity are most likely due to obesity hypoventilation syndrome.
Image Description:

This nomogram can be used for the interpretation of an arterial blood gas analysis in the context of acid-base disorders.

PCO2 is on the x-axis and the concentration of HCO3- (cHCO3-) is on the y-axis; both are displayed logarithmically, allowing the pH to be displayed on parallel straight lines. The important areas for acid-base disorders are highlighted and labeled. The oval area in the middle around PCO2 = 40 mm Hg and cHCO3- = 24 mEq/L represents the reference range.
questions.hint: Using the Winter formula, i.e., expected pCO2 = (1.5 x HCO3-) + 8 (+/- 2), the expected pCO2 for an HCO3- concentration of 16 mEq/L is between 30 and 34 mm Hg.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath and progressive swelling of his legs for 1 week. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include amlodipine and pravastatin. His temperature is 37.5째C (99.5째F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 113/70 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows bilateral coarse crackles. An S3 gallop is heard on auscultation. There is jugular venous distension and pitting edema of both ankles. He is admitted to the hospital, and treatment with intravenous bumetanide is initiated. Serum studies obtained 5 days after admission show:


Na+

138 mEq/L


Cl

101 mEq/L


Mg2+

1.3 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
42 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.8 mg/dL


Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.51


PCO2

52 mm Hg


PO2

60 mm Hg


HCO3-
33 mmol/L


Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The physiologic response to volume depletion includes activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which results in an increased serum aldosterone concentration. Aldosterone can further exacerbate metabolic derangement by increasing renal loss of K+ and H+, which results in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. In addition, volume depletion results in vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, which can lead to acute kidney injury, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Flowchart summarizing the biochemical and physiological effects of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and current pharmacological inhibitors (overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics inhibit the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter, resulting in increased chloride excretion. This leads to an increase, not a decrease, in urine chloride concentration.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has signs of dehydration, prerenal azotemia, and an elevated BUN:creatinine ratio (> 20). These features indicate volume depletion. The physiologic response to volume depletion is an increase, not decrease, in serum renin concentration.

D) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics inhibit the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter, resulting in increased potassium excretion. This leads to a decreased, not increased, serum potassium concentration.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum vasopressin concentrations decrease in conditions of decreased serum osmolality (e.g., fluid overload). With the use of loop diuretics, however, both fluid and electrolytes are lost in equal proportion. Therefore, serum osmolality remains unchanged, and vasopressin concentrations would likely not be affected.
questions.hint: This patient has undergone treatment with a loop diuretic (bumetanide) for decompensated heart failure. The findings of his laboratory studies indicate prerenal azotemia and metabolic alkalosis. These features suggest volume depletion that has led to contraction alkalosis.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to the emergency department because of nausea and abdominal pain during the past 6 hours. His finger stick blood glucose concentration is 409 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows the presence of ketone bodies. Which of the following results of arterial blood gas analysis is most likely before treatment?



pH
PaCO2 (mm Hg)
HCO3- (mEq/L)



A
7.52
52
41


B
7.46
29
20


C
7.28
51
23


D
7.29
30
14


E
7.49
33
24


F
7.34
56
29
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased pH with increased PaCO2 and increased HCO3- suggests a metabolic alkalosis, which is typically caused by severe vomiting, diuretic use, hyperaldosteronism, or Cushing syndrome. This patient can develop a metabolic alkalosis due to severe vomiting and/or hypovolemia but a different primary acid-base disorder would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Mildly increased pH with decreased PaCO2 and decreased HCO3- suggests a respiratory alkalosis that has been compensated for by decreased renal reabsorption of bicarbonate (chronic respiratory alkalosis). Respiratory alkalosis is typically caused by hyperventilation due to anxiety, certain drug toxicities (e.g., aspirin), or mechanical ventilation. This patient with ketonuria will hyperventilate as a compensatory response but the primary acid-base disorder is not a respiratory alkalosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased pH with increased PaCO2 and a normal HCO3- suggests a respiratory acidosis that has not yet been compensated for by the kidneys (acute respiratory acidosis). Respiratory acidosis is typically caused by airway obstruction (e.g., COPD, bronchial asthma) or hypoventilation due to respiratory muscle weakness or CNS depression. A different acid-base disorder would be expected in this patient with ketonuria.

D) CORRECT:

This patient with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with clinical features of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). DKA occurs when insulin deficiency stimulates lipolysis and increases the production of ketone bodies (e.g., acetoacetic acid) from free fatty acids. The presence of these inorganic acids lowers pH and increases the anion gap. In order to buffer these acidic ketones, HCO3- is consumed. To compensate for metabolic acidosis, minute ventilation increases and PaCO2 is lowered, resulting in an arterial blood gas pattern as seen here.
Image Description:

This algorithm does not account for mixed acid-base disorders.

Cl-: chloride
HCO3-: bicarbonate
Na+: sodium
PCO2: partial pressure of carbon dioxide

E) INCORRECT:

Increased pH with decreased PaCO2 and normal HCO3- suggests a respiratory alkalosis that has not yet been compensated for by the kidneys (acute respiratory alkalosis). Respiratory alkalosis is typically caused by hyperventilation due to anxiety, certain drug toxicities (e.g., aspirin), or mechanical ventilation. This patient with ketonuria will hyperventilate as a compensatory response but the primary acid-base disorder is not a respiratory alkalosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Mildly decreased pH with increased PaCO2 and increased bicarbonate suggests a respiratory acidosis that has been compensated for by increased renal reabsorption of bicarbonate (chronic respiratory acidosis). Respiratory acidosis is typically caused by airway obstruction (e.g., COPD, bronchial asthma) or hypoventilation due to respiratory muscle weakness or CNS depression. A different acid-base disorder would be expected in this patient with ketonuria.
questions.hint: This patient with type 1 diabetes mellitus presenting with abdominal pain, nausea, acute hyperglycemia, and ketonuria most likely has an increased anion gap.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 2-day history of fatigue and progressively worsening confusion. He has hypertension and chronic kidney disease that requires hemodialysis. He missed his last dialysis appointment one week ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, he is lethargic and only oriented to person. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine of 5.2 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen level of 78 mg/dL. Which of the following sets of arterial blood gas values is most likely in this patient?



pH
Anion gap
pCO2 (mm Hg)
Bicarbonate (mEq/L)



A
7.28
18
29
15


B
7.49
10
25
28


C
7.51
12
48
33


D
7.37
14
22
14


E
7.31
8
33
18
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A low pH and bicarbonate level with an increased anion gap are consistent with an anion gap metabolic acidosis, which occurs in end-stage renal disease (ESRD) as a result of a build-up of certain acidic anions (e.g., phosphate, sulfate, hippurate, urate). Metabolic acidosis leads to an increase in respiratory drive (respiratory compensation), resulting in a decrease in arterial pCO2 that can be predicted by the Winter formula. If the patient's measured pCO2 falls outside the range of the expected pCO2, a secondary respiratory acid-base disorder (e.g., respiratory acidosis as a result of uremic encephalopathy and CNS depression, respiratory alkalosis due to ESRD-induced pulmonary edema) should be considered.
Image Description:

This algorithm does not account for mixed acid-base disorders.

Cl-: chloride
HCO3-: bicarbonate
Na+: sodium
PCO2: partial pressure of carbon dioxide

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated pH and decreased pCO2 levels are consistent with respiratory alkalosis without metabolic compensation (normal bicarbonate), which occurs due to increased respiratory rate and/or tidal volume (i.e. alveolar hyperventilation). This patient has no signs of hyperventilation or increased tidal volumes. Instead, he has uremia, which puts him at risk of developing a different acid-base disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum pH with increased bicarbonate is consistent with metabolic alkalosis, which occurs due to loss of H+ (e.g., vomiting) or increased production of HCO3- (e.g., contraction alkalosis). The increased serum pH leads to a decrease in respiratory drive (respiratory compensation), resulting in an increased arterial pCO2. Instead, this patient has uremia, which puts him at risk of a different acid-base disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Normal pH with a low bicarbonate and a measured pCO2 that is lower than the expected pCO2 (as per the Winter formula) is consistent with a mixed acid-base disorder of metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis, which would not be expected unless the patient has a complication of end-stage renal disease such as pulmonary edema.

E) INCORRECT:

A low pH, low bicarbonate, and normal anion gap with reduced pCO2 are consistent with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation. This acid-base disorder is caused by loss of bicarbonate and subsequent replacement with chloride ions. It typically occurs secondary to diarrhea, renal tubular acidosis, or certain drugs (e.g., carbonic anhydrase inhibitors). This patient's uremia would lead to a different type of acid-base disorder.
questions.hint: Altered mental status and an elevated blood urea nitrogen level after missed hemodialysis indicate uremia.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of high fever and confusion for the past 10 hours. His wife reports that 1 week ago during a trip to Guatemala he underwent an emergency appendectomy. His temperature is 40.1째C (104.2째F), pulse is 132/min, and blood pressure is 74/46 mm Hg. He is oriented only to person. Physical examination shows a surgical wound in the right lower quadrant with purulent discharge. The skin is warm and dry. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 138 mEq/L, potassium concentration of 3.7 mEq/L, and lactate concentration of 3.5 mEq/L (N = 0.52.2). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.21


PCO2
36 mm Hg


HCO3-
14 mEq/L


O2 saturation
87%


Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory changes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperventilation results in respiratory alkalosis, which manifests with a lower-than-expected pCO2. This patient's pCO2 is higher than predicted by the Winter formula.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with primary adrenal insufficiency who experience an acute stressor, such as a serious infection, have an increased risk of developing shock as a result of adrenal crisis. However, primary adrenal insufficiency typically causes hyponatremia and hyperkalemia (due to hypoaldosteronism), which are not seen here. Additionally, this patient's pCO2 is higher than predicted by the Winter formula, which indicates a secondary acid-base disturbance. Primary adrenal insufficiency would not cause this secondary disturbance.

C) INCORRECT:

Salicylate toxicity typically presents with hyperthermia, altered mental status, and metabolic acidosis. However, salicylates also cause respiratory alkalosis (due to increased respiratory rate resulting from activation of the respiratory center of the medulla), which manifests with a lower-than-expected pCO2 value. This patient's pCO2, however, is higher than predicted by the Winter formula.

D) CORRECT:

Per the Winter formula, a pCO2 of 2731 mm Hg would reflect an appropriate respiratory compensation for this patient's metabolic acidosis. Instead, this patient's pCO2 is 36 mm Hg, which indicates the presence of a respiratory acidosis in addition to the metabolic acidosis. Respiratory acidosis is caused by hypoventilation (e.g., from respiratory fatigue in critically ill patients), which leads to CO2 retention.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetic ketoacidosis can cause hypotension and altered mental status, as seen in this patient, and is often precipitated by an infection. DKA is the initial manifestation of type 1 diabetes mellitus in approximately 30% of cases. However, hallmark symptoms of DKA (e.g., polyuria, polydipsia, nausea, and vomiting) are not seen here. Also, this patient's pCO2 is higher than the Winter formula would predict. DKA often manifests with hyperventilation, which leads to a lower-than-expected pCO2.
questions.hint: This patient has clinical features of septic shock (e.g., fever, tachycardia, hypotension, warm and dry skin) due to infection of his appendectomy surgical site. His metabolic acidosis is likely due to the accumulation of lactic acid from septic shock. Assess for appropriate compensation using the Winter formula: expected pCO2  = (1.5 x HCO3-) + 8 (짹 2).

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset blurry vision, severe upper abdominal pain, and vomiting that started one day after he drank a bottle of paint thinner. Physical examination shows epigastric tenderness without rebound or guarding. Ophthalmologic examination shows a visual acuity of 20/200 bilaterally despite corrective lenses. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.21


Sodium
135 mEq/L


Chloride
103 mEq/L


Bicarbonate
13 mEq/L


An antidote with which of the following mechanisms of action is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetyl-CoA synthetase metabolizes acetate to acetyl-CoA and is downstream in the pathway of alcohol metabolism. Activation of acetyl-CoA synthetase would not affect the metabolism of toxic methanol metabolites.

B) INCORRECT:

Alcohol dehydrogenase converts ingested methanol to formic acid and formaldehyde. Activation of alcohol dehydrogenase would accelerate this conversion, thereby increasing the effects of methanol toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of acetaldehyde dehydrogenase is the mechanism of action of disulfiram, which can help treat alcohol abuse by blocking the degradation of acetaldehyde and increasing the negative side effects from alcohol ingestion (e.g., nausea and vomiting). Disulfiram does not prevent the creation of toxic metabolites like formic acid and formaldehyde and therefore has no role in treating methanol toxicity.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetyl-CoA synthetase metabolizes acetate to acetyl-CoA and is downstream in the pathway of alcohol metabolism. Inhibition of acetyl-CoA synthetase would not affect the metabolism of toxic methanol metabolites.

E) INCORRECT:

Activation of acetaldehyde dehydrogenase would help break down the toxic metabolites of ethanol but does not play a role in the removal of harmful methanol metabolites.

F) CORRECT:

Alcohol dehydrogenase converts ingested methanol into formaldehyde and formic acid, a toxic substance that is responsible for most of the clinical effects seen with methanol intoxication (e.g., CNS depression, decreased visual acuity, blindness, abdominal pain, metabolic acidosis). Fomepizole prevents the conversion of methanol to its toxic byproducts by inhibiting alcohol dehydrogenase. Most industrial alcohols, antifreeze solutions, and windshield wiper fluids contain methanol.

Additionally, folic acid administration can help accelerate the breakdown of formic acid.
Image Description:

Metabolic pathways for methanol and ethylene glycol are shown. Both methanol and ethylene glycol are converted to toxic metabolites (purple boxes) by alcohol dehydrogenase. Alcohol dehydrogenase is inhibited (red boxes) by fomepizole and ethanol. The toxic metabolites are converted to nontoxic metabolites with the help of specific adjunctives (blue boxes).
questions.hint: This patient's abdominal pain, visual changes, and anion-gap metabolic acidosis are consistent with methanol poisoning. The clinical effects of methanol poisoning are related to its metabolism to formic acid.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of dizziness, nausea, and vomiting for 4 days. Her temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.58


PCO2
43 mm Hg


PO2

96 mm Hg


HCO3-
32 mEq/L


The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is measurement of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The urine albumin:creatinine ratio is used to identify glomerular damage and screen for increased risk of developing kidney disease. Diseases that damage the glomerulus (e.g., diabetes and hypertension) cause excess excretion of albumin, raising the albumin:creatinine ratio. It is not helpful for identifying the cause or guiding the management of metabolic alkalosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the serum osmolal gap is useful in determining the etiology of a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, especially when toxic alcohol ingestion (ethanol, methanol, or ethylene glycol) is being considered. It is not helpful in determining the cause or guiding the management of a metabolic alkalosis.

C) CORRECT:

Measurement of urine chloride concentration is useful to determine the etiology of metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic alkalosis associated with a normal urinary chloride concentration (< 25 mmol/L) is called a chloride-responsive metabolic alkalosis because it corrects with administration of fluid with NaCl. It is often secondary to volume loss through vomiting or diuretic use. Metabolic alkalosis associated with an elevated urinary chloride concentration (> 40 mmol/L) is called a chloride-resistant metabolic alkalosis because it does not correct with administration of fluid with NaCl. It is often secondary to conditions such as mineralocorticoid excess and is associated with increased extracellular volume and hypertension.
Image Description:

ABG: arterial blood gas
BMP: basic metabolic panel

D) INCORRECT:

The urine anion gap is measured as a proxy for urinary excretion of NH4+, which is a measure of renal acidification. It is useful in determining whether a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis results from inadequate renal acidification of urine. It is not helpful for determining the cause or guiding the management of a metabolic alkalosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the serum anion gap is useful in determining the cause of a metabolic acidosis. It is not helpful for determining the cause or guiding the management of a metabolic alkalosis.
questions.hint: An arterial blood gas showing a pH of 7.58, PCO2 of 43 mmHg, and HCO3- of 32 mEq/L is consistent with a primary metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effect of overdoses on the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen. An illustration with oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves in two settings is shown. Curve A shows the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve of individual A with an overdose of a specific substance and an arterial pCO2 of 44 mm Hg. Individual A did not vomit following the substance overdose. Curve B shows the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve of individual B who is healthy and has an arterial pCO2 of 44 mm Hg. An overdose with which of the following substances best explains the findings in individual A?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An overdose of opioids (e.g., fentanyl) would cause respiratory depression, which would lead to acidemia due to CO2 retention (respiratory acidosis). Acidemia and hypercapnia shift the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the right.

B) INCORRECT:

Unlike carbon monoxide and substances that cause methemoglobinemia (e.g., nitroglycerin), cyanide does not directly affect the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen. Since cyanide inhibits aerobic metabolism, cyanide poisoning increases anaerobic metabolism and can cause acidemia due to lactic acidosis. Acidemia shifts the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. Compensatory hypocapnia due to metabolic acidosis can shift the curve to the left but individual A is normocapneic.

C) INCORRECT:

An overdose of depolarizing muscle relaxants (e.g., succinylcholine) can trigger malignant hyperthermia (MH). This condition, which is characterized by uncontrollable contraction of skeletal muscle, leads to hypercapnia (due to a hypermetabolic state), lactic acidosis (due to skeletal muscle breakdown and hyperlactatemia), and an increase in body temperature (hyperthermia). These changes would shift the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the right.

D) CORRECT:

An overdose of loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide), thiazide diuretics, or laxatives causes alkalemia due to metabolic alkalosis. An overdose of these substances can be seen in individuals with purging behaviors and contraction alkalosis is the underlying mechanism for metabolic alkalosis. The expected physiological compensation for metabolic alkalosis is a decrease in ventilatory drive and a hypoventilation-induced increase in pCO2. However, the compensatory process in metabolic alkalosis is not as efficient as the one in metabolic acidosis because hypoventilation-induced hypoxia blunts the decrease in ventilatory drive. Therefore, pCO2 levels do not rise substantially and patients with metabolic alkalosis can be normocapneic.
Image Description:

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shows the partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) in blood in relation to the percentage O2 saturation of hemoglobin (HbO2), i.e., the binding affinity of Hb for O2. The curve is sigmoidal (S-shaped), starting with a gradual increase, then rising steeply before plateauing (blue curve).

Factors that decrease the affinity of Hb for O2 (e.g., pCO2) shift the curve to the right (green curve). This increases P50 (the partial pressure of oxygen needed to maintain 50% of Hb saturated). These factors facilitate the release of O2 to the tissues.

Factors that increase the affinity of Hb for O2 (e.g., pCO2) shift the curve to the left (purple curve), with a concomitant decrease in P50.

The variation in the binding affinity of Hb for O2 represented by the sigmoidal shape of the curve is clinically significant, since it means that a decrease in pO2 does not lead to a corresponding linear decrease in % HbO2. Instead, HbO2 initially drops very slowly, but with further decrease in pO2 then drops precipitously:

(A) A pO2 of 90 mmHg corresponds to an HbO2 saturation of 97%.
(B) A decrease of pO2 to 75 mmHg corresponds to a decrease in % HbO2 of only 3% (to 94%).
(C) A further decrease of pO2 to 50 mmHg corresponds to a further decrease in % HbO2 of 10% (to 84%).
questions.hint: Curve A is consistent with a left shift of the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve. Causes of a left shift include alkalemia, hypocapnia, hypothermia, and decreased 2,3-diphosphoglycerate concentration.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old professional runner is preparing for an upcoming competition in a high-altitude training camp in Ethiopia. He usually trains near sea level. The campsite is at 2,800 m (9,200 ft) above sea level, and his training includes several runs to an altitude of 4,000 m (13,000 ft). On the morning of the fourth day of the trip, his blood is drawn by a supervising physician. Which of the following sets of arterial blood gas findings is most likely?
